After the national union told the Madison local to stay on the job, several members walked out anyway, a bold move, but one that led to a re-negotiation of terms between management and labor within twenty-four hours. The company immediately recognized the union, and no major labor stoppages occurred after this; it was path-breaking for Madison's unions and indeed, preceded the Wagner Act's passage by a year.

In addition to employing thousands of Madisonians, the company also benefitted the broader community, in part through their charitable foundation, but also through financial incentives in housing and transportation that benefited workers as well as others on Madison's north side.

As David Mollenhoff has documented in his book on Madison's history, the city experienced a housing slump after World War I; rather than see their employees struggle, Oscar's stepped in to oversee construction of fifty affordable houses for their workers on Madison's east side. The company also paid the private streetcar line to expand to the north side of Madison, thereby providing workers with easy access to their new facility.
author: Anna Andrzejewski

name: Harlow S. & Isabelle C. Ott House
description:
The Harlow S. and Isabelle C. Ott House is a late Victorian house with Queen Anne characteristics and Arts and Crafts leaded glass, oak paneling, and English Gothic details. It was designed and built in 1897-1898 by the young Madison architectural firm of Claude & Starck, who had only formed their architectural partnership in 1896.

The house at 807 Jenifer Street was built for Harlow Sherman and Isabelle C. Ott on the former side yard of the adjacent Holver Gabriel house (see entry). The unusual triangular lot posed a unique design challenge for the architects. They chose to orient the house toward the corner, so that it faced neither Jenifer nor Spaight Streets.

In the manner of designing an "organic" floor plan, akin to those espoused by their progressive peers in the Chicago School of architecture (later the Prairie School), they aligned the "living rooms" along the Spaight Street side and front end of the house. The front of the house was given a rounded room that provided a large turret with a conical roof. This feature, along with a steep roof, attic dormers with peaked gables, Gothic detailing on the porch, and some aspects of the interior, combined to provide a variation on the Queen Anne that had with roots in Shingle Style forms, and aspects of the English Gothic style.

It was the first house in the neighborhood designed by Claude & Starck and only the second or third oldest known house they designed in Madison. Over the following two decades Claude & Starck built many more houses along Spaight Street and Orton Park.

The present owner purchased the house in 1997, reopened it as a single- family home, and restored the badly deteriorated exterior. Fortunately, the ground floor remained protected and still exhibits its grand staircase with a tall oriel that extends toward Jenifer Street. It is believed that the oriel was intended to serve as a lookout for Isabelle Ott as she watched for approaching streetcars during inclement weather.

Especially notable are the simple English patterns of leaded glass situated above the bench and in the oriel window of the stair landing windows. The foyer walls are clad with horizontal battens and narrow beaded strips are also seen in houses designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in 1893. The airlock at the front door entrance and the stair wainscoting reveal two original Lincrusta patterns.

Another non-viewable aspect is the somewhat higher level of finish displayed in the original third-floor maid's room. It is of quarter-sawn white oak trim and has a dormer oriented to the lake. These features were employed by progressive architects in an effort to embrace the hired help, rather than set them entirely apart.

The yard originally was at least partly enclosed with a low woven-wire fence that included Gothic finials on its short posts. Today's garden is referred to by the owner as a pleasant collision of Japanese and English Cottage styled gardens.

The house is currently in the process of further restoration.
author: Gary Tipler

name: Orton Park
description:
Orton Park, a three and one half acre park that comprises all of block 180 in the original 1836 city plat of Madison, was the city's first public park. Prior to 1877, the block served as the site for Madison's first public cemetery. The cemetery was dedicated following incorporation of the village in 1846. By the time Madison became a city in 1857, additional space was needed, and thus land on Madison's west side, which would become Forest Hill Cemetery, was acquired for this purpose.

In 1877, the bodies buried at Orton Park were exhumed and reinterred in Forest Hill. After this, prominent residents of Third Lake Ridge, notably George Ott (see Ott House entry), lobbied the city for a public park. In 1879 Ott raised $100 in individual private subscriptions to convert the block into public space. Orton Park was dedicated in 1883, and was named after a former mayor and then Supreme Court Justice, Harlow S. Orton; it officially opened in 1887. An observer for the Wisconsin State Journal noted, "From 2,000 to 3,000 people gathered under the boughs despite the cool atmosphere and all seemed greatly please with the free entertainment provided."

After the park became a desirable neighborhood amenity, wealthier residents of Third Lake Ridge built houses facing the park on all sides; some were fashionable examples by some of Madison's most well known late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century architects, including Claude and Starck. Prairie and craftsman style houses stand alongside Queen Anne examples, although the mixing of these styles is common as well.

The park has been a central gathering place for Third Lake Ridge ever since 1883. Band concerts were held there during the 1880s and 1890s, and farmers markets and socials have been held at Orton for the past century.

It has been the site of the annual Orton Park festival for many decades. The gazebo was constructed in 1979 by Stuart Gallaher. George Segal's sculpture, "Gay Liberation", was installed for a time beginning in 1986 in the Park.

Orton Park became a local landmark in 1975 and the Orton Park Historic District was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1988.
author: Anna Andrzejewski

name: John George Ott House
description:
The large imposing house at 754 Jenifer Street was built for John George Ott in 1873. Originally designed as an Italianate Villa, the house received significant Victorian ornamentation over time. The house is of frame construction sheathed in brick veneer. The main section is two-and-one-half stories tall; the wings are two stories in height.

A distinctive feature of the house is provided by its windows on the main section; they generally have stone sills with ornately carved lintels. The lintels are arched on the first floor and incised onto the upper story, and while an attempt was made at consistency, differences can be found between windows. Sometime between 1873 and 1892 two additions were made to the original block. One addition on the northeastern side has a side gabled roof and a porch.

The porch contains two doors, one of which was boarded up and is now being used as a window. Another addition, facing west, was added between 1902 and 1908. There have been other changes as the property has transformed into a multi-unit residence, mainly having to do with porch changes. A cupola once stood atop the main section.

John George Ott was a successful entrepreneur in Madison during its early decades and the house is a testament to the wealth that businessmen like Ott attained. Ott was a German-Swiss Immigrant who came to Madison in 1850 when he was twenty-three years old. He owned a brickyard on this property; the bricks for the house were likely made here.

Ott also established a grocery store along nearby Williamson Street near the corner with Livingston (just down the street from his house), and eventually he went into the insurance business.

The house may be compared in its grandeur to others in the vicinity that date to this era, such as the Holver Gabriel House. In its scale and Italianate features, it certainly draws on popular styles of the time seen in pattern books. Yet its construction of locally produced red bricks (rather than the then-faddish Milwaukee cream city bricks) and its unusual lintels suggest a desire on the part of the owner to create a distinctive house and not just another elite mansion.

Ott was a prominent figure in Third Lake Ridge. He was very active in civic affairs; he served on the Madison City Council and Dane County Board. He founded several notable clubs, including the German Masonic Lodge, the Turnevein, and the Maennerchoir.

Ott also lobbied for the conversion of the former public graveyard site down the street into a public park. He lived at this house until the time of his death. His son, Harlow S. Ott, became a successful pharmacist, and built a house across the street from his parents during the late 1890s.

Following Ott's death his daughter, Alma, lived with her husband, Frederick Lacher, in the house. Like many other large houses in the neighborhood, it has since become a multi-unit rental property. The house is a Madison Landmark and a contributing element to the Third Lake Ridge landmark district.
author: Michelle Oyen, Erin Kauppinen, Andrew Baird, and James Wright

name: Kleuter Wholesale Grocery Warehouse
description:
Towering high above the commercial and industrial buildings nearby, the five-story structure at 901 East Washington Avenue was originally a grocery warehouse. The red brick and reinforced concrete construction materials provided not only a fireproof building, but also the structural strength needed for a tall, spacious warehouse. Abundant large windows provided efficient light for the work and storage areas throughout. The structure was built by the Wisconsin Construction Company of Madison for $55,000.

The subtle Prairie-style accents and proportions distinguish this building from the more utilitarian and simply-finished warehouses and workshops located nearby. One of the structure's defining features are the three square towers, each decorated with geometric ornamental designs within the parapet. The use of horizontal raised-brick banding on the first and fifth levels, and raised-brick quoins on the square towers, further emphasizes the building's Prairie-style influence.

The Kleuter Wholesale Company chose noted Madison-based Prairie style architect Alvan Small to design their new building. Small began his apprenticeship in 1887 with the notable Madison firm, Conover & Porter; spent a year in Chicago in the office of Louis Sullivan; and then returned to Madison in 1900.

He practiced for twenty-five years before retiring in 1926. Several Madison structures designed by Small are listed in the National Register of Historic Places, but the Kleuter Wholesale Grocery Warehouse (deemed eligible in 2002) is considered one of Small's non-residential structures influenced by the Prairie style. The Olds Seed Company Building is another example of Small's non-residential work.

Industry and development flourished on Madison's near East Side and the Kleuter Wholesale Company, like other businesses in Third Lake Ridge, took advantage of the proximity to rail lines for their grocery wholesale firm. They had operated their warehouse on East Wilson Street since about 1868, but by 1915, needed additional space. The Kleuter Brothers sold Badger Brand canned goods, among other items.

In 1927 Jerry and Emanuel Simon purchased the business and warehouse building, at which time it became known as Simon Brothers Wholesale Groceries. The Simon Brothers switched to liquor distribution in 1935, a little over a year after Prohibition ended, and utilized the warehouse until 1979.

The building was most recently occupied by the Mautz Paint Company, a local firm that got its start in 1892 as a paint and wallpaper store. Following years of hard work and the manufacture of their paint products, Mautz relocated to 939 East Washington Avenue in 1942, just east of the Kleuter warehouse. Mautz purchased the former warehouse from the Simon Brothers Company in 1979 to boost production and add warehouse space.

By 1985, Mautz was producing 1.3 million gallons of paint a year and by 2000 their annual sales totaled nearly $33 million. In November 2001, the Sherwin-Williams Co. purchased the Mautz brand, its formula, and its thirty three stores. The former Kleuter Warehouse Building, however, was not part of the transaction, and is currently for sale. Its location on the East Washington corridor makes it a prime candidate for adaptive reuse, and several proposals are under consideration.
author: Mark Speltz

name: Fauerbach House
description:
The Fauerbach House, a Greek Revival side-passage frame dwelling built in 1856, represents a common form and popular style in Third Lake Ridge during the first few decades of development. Its history shows the path of assimilation of a prominent German family, the Fauerbachs, during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries as well as the changing uses of dwellings such as this in the neighborhood. Although its basic form is readable today, the house has undergone many changes that make its interpretation difficult on the basis of the built fabric alone.

The Fauerbach House was built by Erastus Wyman, a Yankee carpenter from New York. Initially a carpenter, Wyman eventually went into business and opened a lumberyard. Wyman's relative affluence is suggested by the stylish attributes of the house as well as its location within a cluster of homes of wealthy early Madisonians; next door stood the imposing Shipley-Shuttleworth House and across the street was Farwell's Octagon House (now demolished).

The front-facing gable, intact cornice returns, and symmetrical placement of the windows (with the exception of the replaced picture window on the first floor) are hallmarks of the Greek Revival style. Interior elements, such as the original newel post and door casings in the front passage and elsewhere in the house, also suggest the original owner's affluence. It is also possible that the house had a one-story colonnaded entry porch. Recent renovations revealed that the frame house originally had brick nogging.

Henry Fauerbach, part owner of the Fauerbach Brewery, purchased the house in 1890. One of the city's oldest and most successful breweries, Fauerbach Brewery was started in 1868 by Henry's father, Peter, an immigrant from Fauerbach, Germany. He initially leased the Sprecher Brewery building and eventually purchased it in 1878.

Peter and his wife, Maria, had six sons: Louis, Philip, Henry, Charles, Emil, and William. Upon Peter's death in 1886, Maria ran the business for five years until 1891. At that point, the four oldest children assumed company leadership, with Charles eventually going into other occupations outside of the brewery and Emil entering the business when he became old enough.

Under the leadership of this second generation of Fauerbachs, the brewery would experience levels of growth that Peter could never have imagined. In 1878, after running the business for ten years, the brewery had the capacity to produce 1,500 barrels of beer per year. By 1907 Fauerbach Brewing Co. had twenty cellar tanks, each with the capacity to hold 240 barrels of beer for a total of 4,800 barrels of beer at one time.

Prohibition and the Great Depression dealt a severe blow to the Fauerbach Brewing Company. The fact the brewery managed other interests, including rental housing, partly kept them afloat for a time. Nevertheless, the Fauerbachs were forced to foreclose on the house in 1927.

The brewery was the only one in Madison to survive prohibition; however, it fell victim to the growth of large commercial breweries and ultimately closed in 1966. The Fauerbach House remained a multi-unit rental property until 1985 when the current owners purchased it. They have since been working on restoring the property, and have converted it back to a single-family dwelling.
author: Kimberly Hernandez, Amy Brabender, and Jared Lowery

name: Hyers Hotel
description:
Hyer's Hotel was built in 1854, the same year the railroad first reached Madison. The building is the oldest surviving hotel in Madison. Italianate in style, it was originally constructed with soft locally produced red brick laid in a five-course common bond. Sandstone sills and lintels provide decorative accents, as does an ornate bracketed cornice.

The house originally consisted of the two-story brick main block with a wood frame ell to the rear, which had a stable for visitors' horses behind it. An 1874 fire destroyed the wing and stables. When the house was later converted into a single-family residence, a small brick wing was added where the frame wing once stood.

David Hyer, the builder and first owner, was a member of the first group of settlers to arrive in Madison in 1837; he was employed by Augustus A. Bird in the construction of the first Capitol Building. After trying his luck in the 1848 California Gold Rush, Hyer purchased lots ten and eleven of Block 148 from Leonard Farwell, a prominent land speculator. Tax assessments prior to the construction of the hotel valued the lots at three hundred dollars. After construction of the hotel and livery the property was valued at $2,300. Hyer then sold the property in 1855 to proprietor Henry Jaquish for $9,000, an indication of the boom that was then occurring in Third Lake Ridge.

The second owner, Henry Jaquish, came to Madison by way of Mineral Point during the lead boom. After a short stint in Mineral Point, he farmed for several years in the village of Mazomanie (western Dane County) before purchasing Hyer's Hotel. Jaquish ran the hotel until the fire in 1874, and lived in the brick portion with his family.

Jacquish's sale came at a time when the hotel business was saturated. The 1875 Madison city directory reveals a total of twenty-six hotels in Madison, seven of them near the railroad depot. After selling the hotel, Jacquish and his wife remained in the Third Lake Ridge, purchasing a house at 1026 Williamson Street. Following the fire, the building functioned as a single-family residence. Joseph E. Kleiner, president of the Madison Candy Company, purchased the house in 1900. As was true of many other executives associated with area industries, Kleiner lived within walking distance of his company, but also lived along side working-class residents.

The occupancy of Hyer's Hotel during those first twenty years provides an interesting window into Third Lake Ridge. It appears the hotel provided transient lodging for those seeking work in the growing Third Lake Ridge corridor. The 1858 Madison city directory lists the following residents: two carpenters, two painters, a blacksmith, a laborer, a cabinet-maker, a bookkeeper, a tailor, a feed store employee, and Jaquish. The 1860 manuscript census reveals a similar range of occupations. An even mix of and foreign-born immigrants and East Coast migrs residing in the neighborhood with their families and young children.

The house continued to operate as a single-family residence during much of the twentieth century. In 1910, Art and Genevieve Schulkamp purchased the house, and lived there through his death in 1972. Schulkamp was a prominent banker, insurance agent, and philanthropist in Madison.

In 1915, the Schulkamps extensively remodeled the structure by knocking out walls to provide open living spaces that were more in keeping with the progressive styles of the period. The porch was also extended at this time, and other changes were made to the interior with new French doors and modern fixtures. Today the building houses several apartments. Hyer's Hotel became a Madison Landmark in 1975 and was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1983.
author: Jared Lowery

name: Holver Gabriel House
description:
Along with other sizable houses in its vicinity, including the John George Ott House standing cattycorner to it, the Holver Gabriel House suggests the affluence of some Third Lake Ridge residents during the first two decades of settlement. Built in 1866, the house was constructed in two sections: a main two-story block, and a slightly shorter two-story side ell. Both sections are built of the then fashionable Milwaukee cream city brick.

The form of the house represents an update of a popular house form in Third Lake Ridge: the side passage double-pile house (also known as the two-thirds Georgian form). The form was popular in the neighborhood during the first few decades, especially in Greek Revival, examples, including the Fauerbach House and another example across the Street from the Holver Gabriel House at 820 Jenifer Street. In the Holver Gabriel House, the form has been upgraded in several significant ways.

The more faddish Italianate style, replete with its flat roof and roof brackets, has replaced the previously modish Greek Revival. In addition, the house has been updated with interior trim in keeping with the style. The casings at the Holver Grabriel House match those found in the neighborhood's other affluent houses from this period.

This house likely had a basement kitchen. Part of this may have been the siting of the house on a hill sloping towards the lake, but the location of the kitchen also suggests a desire to segregate service functions that became increasingly pronounced in the period. Also notable is the early, if not original, side ell, also built to segregate rooms by function.

Holver Gabriel, a Norwegian immigrant boot and shoemaker, had this house built in 1866. Born in Norway, Gabriel changed his name from Gabrielson" between 1860 and 1870 to make it soundless Norwegian. The morphology of Gabriel's name compares favorably with his architectural tastes; he chose a conventional Italianate Villa (likely generated from popular pattern books) versus a more traditional form.

Unfortunately, it is not known who built the house and little is known about Gabriel and his business beyond the movement of his activities around Madison three times between 1866 and 1875.

By 1883, Gabriel had sold the house to Hiram Moulton, a builder and contractor from Vermont. Moulton came to Wisconsin in 1854 and initially lived on a farm of 143 acres in the Township of Burke, located about eight miles outside of Madison. Moulton had built several buildings in Madison prior to moving there, including a prominent hotel, so his move to Third Lake Ridge likely related to his business. Like Gabriel, Moulton intended that the house convey his wealth and prominence in the community.

Prominent residents continued to live at 811 Jenifer Street but their occupations reflect changes in Third Lake Ridge due to industrialization. The next two residents both worked at agricultural machinery shops on the growing "Implement Row"

Instead of segregating themselves in suburban enclaves, these wealthy residents distinguished themselves from their working class neighbors in other ways. The Holver Gabriel House partly stood out because of its imposing size and prominent Victorian ornament, but later changes to the house also served to signify the wealth of its occupants.

Most significant was the large rear porch added during the closing years of the nineteenth century. This provided a prominent lake view, something increasingly valued by this time. The shoreline of Lake Monona was filled in around the turn of the century, and new houses were erected so as to take advantage of the lakeside views.

Other houses, including the Harlow S. and Isabelle C. Ott House located next door, had two front facades from the start (a street and lake front). The addition of the porch to the rear of this house likely functioned in a similar context.
author: Jared Lowery and Sydney Dobkin

name: Madison Candy Company
description:
The Madison Candy Company was incorporated on 15 February 1899. This building, which emerged in 1903, was the company's second (the first was located at 625 Williamson Street). Local architect and engineer John Nader designed the new three-story brick building. lt was built in a vernacular commercial style typical of many late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century industrial and commercial structures along Williamson Street and within the east side industrial corridor.

The rectangular building measures forty-five feet wide and sixty feet long; the only addition is a small loading dock on the rear elevation installed in 1980. The load bearing walls measure over a foot thick. Red brick is used on the facade, while cream city bricks make up the side and rear walls.

The building is capped by a shed roof, which is partially concealed by a front parapet. Ornament is limited to the main facade; the parapet has rusticated concrete caps punctuated by two windows and a central datestone. Windows have curved segmental arched lintels. Concrete is used to distinguish the beltcourses.

Besides the rear dock and replacement windows, the only major alteration to the exterior of the building occurred when Williamson Street was widened in 1950; at that time, a large exterior staircase was moved inside the lobby area. The interior has been heavily remodeled.

The multiple chimney stacks on the building suggest that confectionary operations likely occurred on all floors. Some large beams evident on the first floor suggest the loads of equipment and products that the building once contained. The large and extensive windows on the front and back also suggest that natural lighting was used to illuminate the interior workspace.

The Madison Candy Company was a prominent confectionary business on the city's industrial east side during the early twentieth century. In 1903, Joseph E Kleiner, president of the company, and his partners, Frank Mosel and T.F. and James Prendergast, lived in the Third Lake Ridge neighborhood, as did many of the company's employees. Kleiner originally lived at 854 Jenifer Street (formerly Hyer's Hotel, see entry), the Prendergast family resided at 731 Jenifer Street, and Frank Mosel lived at 939 Jenifer Street.

Business must have been steady since all of these individuals built prominent architect-designed houses in Third Lake Ridge before 1910.

After the Madison Candy Company closed, the building went through a number of commercial uses. The Richard Ela Welding Company occupied the building for several decades during the middle of the twentieth century; and an agricultural implement shop was also housed there for a period.

A Madison City Landmark, the Candy Company building currently houses a restaurant (El Dorado Grill), a coffeehouse (Ground Zero), and office space. Historic photographs of the building are hung on the interior walls.
author: Jared Lowery

name: Machinery Row
description:
Designed by Conover and Porter, "Machinery Row" is a series of Romanesque-revival style buildings sporadically constructed for agricultural implement houses between 1898 and 1914. The Williamson Street structures were constructed as follows: 601-607 (1898); 621-623 (1899); 613-615 (1901); 625-627 (1902); and 609-611 (sometime after 1902). By 1899, companies such as the Advance Thresher Company, Case J.I. Threshing Company, Champion Harvesting Machinery, Milwaukee Harvester Company, Osborn D.M. and Company, and Syracuse Chilled Plow Company were all located in Machinery Row.

The headquarters of these companies were in other midwestern cities where the agricultural implements were manufactured, but field offices such as those in Madison helped the businesses reach broader markets. The Machinery Row offices combined showroom space, service centers, and financial offices.

Machinery Row is actually a series of brick buildings designed behind a unified facade. It is built largely of Milwaukee "cream city" bricks with stone and tile trim on a sturdy sandstone foundation. Distinguishing features include the tower at the northwestern corner and the crenellated cornice on the street facade. Modern changes mainly involve door and window openings and replacement doors and sash.

Another major change occurred when rail sidings were removed from behind the building where the modern parking lot is located.

Machinery Row was part of Madison's industrial sector, collectively known as "Implement Row." This label referred to a set of dealers who occupied several blocks on Williamson Street and adjacent Blount Street, where they clustered near the railroad. Before the current structure was erected, the property housed a series of wood-framed structures that catered to the tobacco and ice harvesting industries.

As more railroads came to Madison and existing spurs were improved, agricultural implement companies seized on the opportunity to sell their products. In 1898 a wealthy banker who acknowledged the demand bought the Daggett-Hill Property and started to replace the wooden structures in piecemeal fashion with existing buildings. By 1902 the property was listed as Madison's second highest taxpayer.

Almost as soon as Madison experienced a sharp rise in agricultural implement houses, consolidation occurred in the industry. In 1902 J.P. Morgan brokered a merger between McCormick and five other implement companies to form the International Harvester Company (IHC). This move gave IHC a massive amount of capital, along with manufacturing facilities and intellectual property that the smaller implement companies could not compete against.

The decline in agricultural implement companies that subsequently occurred is reflected in the 1907 Madison City Directory, which lists seventeen implement branches. Likewise, Machinery Row reflects the same pattern. In 1904 seven implement companies were listed at the address, but by 1907 there were only three.

As industrial properties moved out of Machinery Row, commercial uses took over, which is how the building functions today. It is a contributing element to the Third Lake Ridge Landmark District and also serves as a local Madison Landmark.
author: Jared Lowery

name: Klose Cottage
description:
The residence known locally as the Klose Cottage" is an upright and wing house built in 1863. A woodframe house, it is clad with clapboard and vertical board siding. Many of the original four over four windows remain, as do the original doors and interior trim. The property has changed relatively little during the past one hundred and fifty years; only a bump-out bathroom was added off the rear when the house was converted into a two-unit building in 1959. The fact that it has experienced so little change makes the Klose Cottage perhaps the best surviving example of a once ubiquitous house form in the Third Lake Ridge neighborhood.

According to Tom Hubka, upright and wings (also known as cross-wings, temple front and wings, and other labels) are distinguished by their T-shaped massing. The T-shape allows for the separation of distinct portions of the house by function. The kitchen is usually in the side-gabled wing, as is evident at the Klose Cottage. The more formal public spaces of the house are in the "upright" (front gabled) portion of the house, which in this example is entered through a second front door (a common variation).

Despite its widespread popularity nationally, there is no agreement (even locally) about what to call this popular house type. The popular development of this plan followed early nineteenth-century Western expansion, and it became a dominant Midwestern farmhouse form. The Klose Cottage and countless other examples show it was just as popular in urban settlements throughout the Midwest as well as elsewhere.

Although the home is associated with a later owner, it was built originally for James Ledwith. He was born in Ireland in 1839 and immigrated to the United States in 1848, likely fleeing the potato famine. He lived in Troy, New York, until 1855 and then moved to Madison. There is no evidence of any other Ledwiths in Wisconsin at this time so it is likely he made the journey west by himself at the age of sixteen.

The 1858 Madison city directory lists Ledwith, a blacksmith, as boarding at the Wisconsin House (likely Wisconsin Inn on Williamson Street). In 1860 he married Ellen Whalen, also an Irish immigrant, and that year they had their first child.

Ledwith's house was built during the early years of the boom (1850s and early 1860s) in the Third Lake Ridge neighborhood. Some of this activity was due to the rise of lumber mills as well as new materials brought in by the railroad; the paper continued by noting that "one stimulus to building this season is the fact that materials are much cheaper, as we are informed, than usual."

Although the panic of 1857 quelled building activity somewhat, it did not cease; Ledwith, for example, needed a new house for his family, which now included a new baby. Therefore, Ledwith, a blacksmith and a wagon maker, built the house himself in 1863. Aldolph Klose, a German tailor, was the next resident of 748 Jenifer; he lived there sometime from the 1870s through 1886.

After this, the house went through a series of residents, most of whom worked at working-class occupations associated with industries in Third Lake Ridge. These include Andrew Hippenmeyer, Jr., a butcher (1886-1902); Hugo Vogel, a collector at MG&E (1907-1946); and several individuals who, during the later twentieth century, worked for the railroad or at nearby Gisholt Manufacturing Company.
author: Julia Griffith and Jared Lowery

name: L.L. Olds Seed Company
description:
The activities that took place inside the L. L. Olds Seed Company affected many acres of land beyond the Third Lake Ridge neighborhood. Founded in 1888 as a mail order company operating out of Clinton, Wisconsin (between Madison and Chicago), Olds Seed was a large seed packer and distributor with a national market. After expanding beyond its mail order business, the company, in 1914, erected its headquarters at 722 Williamson, where a rail line was available to facilitate the distribution of Old Seeds products. Initially the company specialized in potatoes but gradually expanded, eventually developing a large line of seeds that were used by people who wished to maintain neatly manicured suburban lawns and gardens.

The Olds Seed Company building is a four-story structure built of steel reinforced concrete clad in brick veneer. It was designed in 1914 by Alvan Small, a locally renowned Prairie-school architect. Minimal prairie-style detailing may be seen at the roofline and around the doorways, although it is largely similar to the industrial and commercial buildings found throughout Madison's east side corridor. A streamlined neo-classical doorway is found on the eastern end of the facade.

L.L. Olds, founder of the company that bears his name, was born in Rock County, Wisconsin, and grew up on a potato farm near Clinton. Olds started his mail order catalog company in 1888 by mailing out five hundred copies of a catalog that emphasized his specialty: potatoes. All of the seeds came from a single source: his two hundred acre farm. In 1893 Olds Seed participated in the Columbian World's Exposition (Chicago) and exhibited sixty-five varieties of potatoes, including one new variety. Their catalog not only included potatoes, but also corn, oats, barely, and a few garden seeds. In 1895 Olds doubled the capacity of the warehouse on his farm and eventually built a new three-story facility located along the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad tracks in Clinton. Although a 1908 a fire destroyed this warehouse (and a $24,000 inventory), the company was growing at such a pace that the conflagration did little to slow its growth.

Olds Seed moved to Madison in 1908, originally to Wilson Street and eventually to the handsome headquarters at 722 Williamson. Although Olds could have chosen either Chicago or Rockford, Illinois, as a location for his business, he was interested in Madison because of its good rail connections and proximity to the University of Wisconsin. His move to Madison demonstrates the degree to which he valued agricultural research. Olds briefly lived in the Third Lake Ridge neighborhood at 840 Spaight Street before moving to Madison's near west side suburb of University Heights.

Olds Seeds remained in the building until 1972, at which point it relocated elsewhere in Madison. The building has gone through a number of subsequent transformations a part of adaptive reuse efforts, but still retains its basic exterior form.
author: Jared Lowery

name: Mosel House
description:
The Mosel House is a two-and-one-half story foursquare with notable arts and crafts details. It was built as an eight-bedroom single-family home between 1909 and 1911, and has since served as a multi-family residence and most recently as the Syntropy Co-op. The Mosel House is an excellent example of the arts and crafts style that was popular in Third Lake Ridge during the first two decades of the twentieth century.

Despite many shifts in occupancy, the house retains much of its original form and wonderful interior arts and crafts details. The foursquare form is readily apparent, with the basic four room over four room" configuration still obvious even as the rooms in the upper floors have been subdivided. Arts and crafts details are most evident in the leaded glass windows on the first floor as well as the woodwork.

Particularly notable is the elaborate first-floor fireplace mantle with ionic pilasters and intricate carved detail. The brick one-story porch is also original to the house (though modified numerous times), and only a few modest changes have been made to the footprint at the rear, most prior to the publication of the 1942 Sanborn map.

Perhaps designed by local architect Ferdinand Kronenberg, the house was built for Frank and Emma Mosel and their five children, who lived there between the time it was constructed and 1930. Frank Mosel worked at the Brewer-Mosel Auto Company (as president) and was also the treasurer of the Madison Candy Company, both within easy walking distance of the house.

The Mosels lost the home during the Depression, during which time it passed through a series of owners and was likely a rental property for a period. Benjamin and Mabel Cowan purchased the house in 1942 and owned it through the 1970s. During this period they housed a number of lodgers.

After the house was sold in 1972, it operated as the headquarters of the Lion Players Theater and eventually became a co-op; initially the Sufi Co-Op operated there, and in 1983 it became the Syntropy Co-op under the ownership of the Madison Community Cooperative.
author: Julia Griffith, Christine Huerta, Julie Jones and Olivia Zabel

name: Madison Gas & Electric Powerhouse
description:
The original section of the Madison Gas and Electric (MG&E) Powerhouse was built in 1902, with a large addition erected in 1915. According to the Wisconsin Historical Society's website, the "Neoclassical designs for both portions, symbolized the power of early twentieth century institutions and helped to market an image of this private utility as a "public servant." Numerous additions to the power plant are the result of the need to increase capacity for a growing population as well as new technology. Because the company was privately owned, the additions also symbolize increased profits the company realized as the sole provider of gas and electricity in Madison. By 1912 MG&E employed 119 people; the 1939 figure grew to 270 employees, many of who lived in Third Lake Ridge.

The MG&E Powerhouse occupies a block bounded by Railroad Avenue and South Blount, East Main, and South Livingston Streets. The powerhouse faces South Blount. The main (western) facade is divided into two sections that have discrete functions. The northernmost section functions as the generator house, while the southernmost contains the boiler house.

As the plant expanded to the rear, the functions were largely maintained in the same sections. The prominent Madison architectural firm of Claude and Starck designed the facades, while the Chicago-based engineering firm of Mead and Seastone was responsible for the design of the actual plant.

The exterior walls of the 1902 and 1915 sections are built in red brick, which rest on a concrete foundation faced with stone.

The neo-classical appearance of the 1902 facade, which displays brick pilasters that breakup the long wall and a centrally-placed stone entry with simplified classical surrounds, masks the industrial function of the building; as the Madison Landmark nomination for the property states, the building could "look like a library." The 1915 section contains many features seen in the 1902 unit, though it looks more industrial, partly because of the multi-pane industrial windows that pierce the walls.

In general, similar neo-classical details are found in this section. It should be noted, however, that some craftsman features exist in places, such as the north facade, which reflects the fact Claude and Starck often worked in more "progressive" modes. A modern wall (built in 2000) now obscures the building's southern wall. Later additions, most revealing an industrial-commercial style, are found elsewhere on the property.

MG&E was a major employer on Madison's industrial east side during the twentieth century, and also served as a critical utility for other businesses. Power was needed to supply the machine shops on the east side, such as Fuller and Johnson and Gisholt Machines (at one time the fifth largest machine maker in the country), to name just two of the major players.

The plant has recently (in late 2011) been converted from a coal-burning facility to one that only utilizes natural gas. There are no plans to retire the plant, although MG&E is currently pursuing renewable energy sources, which may affect the facility's future.
author: Jared Lowery

name: Timothy and Katherine McCarthy House
description:
The Timothy and Katherine McCarthy House is a well-preserved example of a Queen Anneresidence, readily apparent with its expansive porches, bay windows, Victorian ornamentation, and elaborate interior. The two-and-one-half story frame house was designed by the Madison based architectural firm of Conover & Porter. It is clad with narrow clapboard siding and rests on a rose-colored sandstone foundation. The house has a complex hipped roof with several cross gables. Ironwork on the north side is original, as are prominent patterned brick and stone chimneys. Prominent Madison builder and contractor T.C. McCarthy built the home to serve the dual purpose of residence and business office.

One of the most striking aspects of the McCarthy House is its well-preserved interior. The first floor plan is largely intact, as is much of the woodwork, metal hardware, and other interior features. The entry vestibule contains a leaded glass window and Lincrusta Walton wainscoting, both of which are original. Much of the interior woodwork is done in white oak, including the newel post, dining room wainscoting, and fireplace surrounds. The woodwork on the second floor is primarily Douglas fir, except for the master bedroom, which uses oak to match the first floor. An elaborate, highly crafted stairhall provides access to the first-floor music room and parlor, which are divided by large original pocket doors. The stairhall woodwork is complemented by wood details in the dining room and parlor. A service stair off the kitchen provides access to a second-floor servant's bedroom. The master bedroom also contains a fireplace, with ornamentation similar to that of the fireplace in the parlor.

Timothy C. (T.C.) McCarthy was a prominent Madison builder and contractor during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. McCarthy was responsible for many prominent public buildings, beginning with his first known commission, the 1883 Dane County Courthouse. He was born in Buffalo, New York, in 1853; and came to Madison in 1854, initially working as a stonemason under David Stevens. McCarthy started his own firm shortly thereafter, specializing in bricklaying and masonry. McCarthy experienced large-scale success when he began working with the architects Allan Conover and Lew Porter. With them, he would build several prominent University of Wisconsin campus buildings, including the Armory/Gymnasium (Red Gym), Science Hall, and Agricultural Hall. At the time of McCarthy's death in 1928, his obituary characterized him as the leading contractor in Madison prior to 1910.

Given his financial success, it is interesting to note that McCarthy built his home in the increasingly dense, industrializing, working-class landscape of Third Lake Ridge in 1897. During this time new neighborhoods on the west side such as Wingra Park and University Heights were being developed for upper class Madisonians, and Connover and Porter were involved with their development. Perhaps it was his economic interest in the neighborhood, where Connover and Porter were active, or it may have been the fact Third Lake Ridge remained, even as it changed somewhat with the industrial boom of the later nineteenth century, becoming a place where middling and upper-class residents lived alongside one another. McCarthy lived at 848 Jenifer until 1928 when he passed away in his home.

Like many older structures in Third Lake Ridge, the house has undergone a series of transformations. After the home passed out of the McCarthy family in 1930, it was broken up into rental apartments. During the 1970s it became a home for delinquent boys. The current owner began restoring the property in 1988 and returned it to its single-family use. The preservation of the interior is remarkable, given the half-century of rental use. The house is a Madison Landmark, and a contributing element to the Third Lake Ridge local historic district.
author: Brittany Breeze, Emma Stepien, Lauren Slattery, and Jared Lowery

name: Heitkamp Wagon Maker Shop
description:
The Heitkamp Wagon Maker Shop illustrates a common "mixed use" form in the Third Lake Ridge neighborhood. The gable-fronted structure was first constructed in 1872 by William Heitkamp for his trade and residence. Heitkamp and his sons worked out of the building for close to two decades. It is built of soft locally-produced red brick; some of the windows reveal original stone sills and lintels.

Heitkamp immigrated to Wisconsin from Prussia in 1855 and first moved to Cottage Grove (about ten miles southwest of downtown Madison), where he became a farmer.

He started purchasing property in Madison in 1862 and in 1865 purchased lot number two on block 148 from George Delaplaine, a wealthy land owner and secretary of the United States Commission on Public Buildings, who owned large amounts of land in and outside of Madison. Heitkamp apprenticed as a blacksmith and used this experience when he opened the Wagon Maker Shop.

Like other structures on the southeastern side of Williamson Street, the Heitkamp Wagon Maker Shop is banked into a hill.

This puts the basement on street level, which allows space for production and easy wagon access while providing domestic space above. This was a common configuration in the Third Lake Ridge neighborhood before 1900, where living quarters sat atop workspaces.

The building has undergone few significant changes in its form and massing. A side addition, evident in an 1890 photograph, was present briefly, but according to Sanborn Fire Insurance maps, was demolished between 1898 and 1902. The most notable changes have been in the use of the building.

After several decades, it was bought by carriage-makers Adam Gelger and Ole Williamson, and acted as the location for their business as well as a rental property. During this time, Gelger's son, John, lived with his family in the property, and continued his business of making carriages until the following year. From 1901 through 1930, the building existed either only as an apartment or, for two short, separate stints, as the location for home laundry services.

The most significant change in use started in 1931 when the structure became the location for Auto Radiator Service under the ownership of M. Erma Wilcox. While it went through many different owners and name changes, the building, for nearly forty years, remained as some sort of automobile garage or repair shop.
author: Ben Blohoweak, Sarah McCarty, Jack Mclaughlin, Kendall Parisi, Becca Rosenberg, and Hanna Shesto
